uh by you know evolution more and more enterprises are going to have more and more clouds and when that happens

to some extent do have some impediments now these impediments are going away uh

but I think as more and more different database providers you know different platform providers are launching on

uh but having said that uh the resources and attributes are definitely distinct
and as you built and most enterprises have built their evolution into cloud uh
into one service provider uh elements like the attributes the variables the

services uh that you know we may just evolve naturally with our comfort zone
into one cloud service provider when you're migrating the application you got to think about how are you going to
migrate all of that as much as possible seamlessly to another cloud uh and and
keep that as discrete as possible so that you have the ability and the agility and the nimleness to do that

see clients run into in fact you know uh this is a common element is the IM

one of the elements that sometimes gets overlooked uh when you're migrating from cloud to cloud and associated with that
are the risk compliance security and governance policies
uh you know I'll give you a simple example we are working with a few of our clients and over the years they have built some custom policy environments

uh now they are migrating from one public cloud provider to the other other public cloud provider they want to be

policy postures it could be things like NIST it could be PII it could be PCI it
could be GDPR they want to make sure that the amount of effort and intelligence that they have built and
they have uh taken time to build around the particular application all of those
also comply and move and they are not starting from scratch uh again uh
finally you know we all build integrations uh across accounts it could
be across services across applications uh we want to make sure that all of them

resources very differently from each other for example the way Azure handles

cloud-tocloud migration is not as difficult and painful at use as it used
to be a few years ago uh and as you are thinking about cloud-tocloud migration
you all are here i'm sure at some point of time you're going to run into this this is becoming a more common phenomena
and as cloud becomes more commodity we're going to see more and more cloud migrations a few things to keep in mind
one is having a robust tool and you know a little bit of a plug here for stack
genen uh a platform like stack genen that automates a large part of that migration at the application layer would
be a key to success because so that you don't have to sit down and do this
manually from one cloud to the other cloud some data points for you uh we
have spoken and we are working with large clients that are doing very large migrations from one cloud to the other
cloud what we find is in the absence of a tool uh you're going to be doing
manual mapping of resources of attributes of variables of policies and
that could take weeks or months uh in fact with one of our clients uh their
initial estimate to do uh you know application migration just for one
moderately complex application just the mapping itself was going to be weeks uh
in terms of the time elapsed and the effort that was going to take because they had to do everything manually not
to mention that uh in many times the source cloud uh
expertise exists but the destination cloud expertise does not exist with the team uh that's trying to make these
migrations they have to learn about the new cloud they have to understand the new cloud they have to understand the
nuances of how uh the services or the APIs or the resources and the treatment
of the attributes and dependencies changes from one cloud to the other cloud so having a tool definitely is a
very important uh element of it the second thing that we have heard and we have seen in live environments is most
of us most clients businesses do not have a robust
uh footprint um you could call a bill of materials or a comprehensive control of
every single resource in their runtime cloud so how do you make sure that when
you're migrating you're actually doing a very tight migration at the deepest
level so having the ability to scan the runtime cloud reverse engineer and then
create the target cloud is a very important capability that you need to look for when you go out there and look
for a tool that gives you that ability to migrate from one cloud to the other doing it manually leads to significant
errors and you know misses uh across the board uh what we have found working with
clients is when we do this in an automated manner we actually find quite a few good surprises for them where
they're able to optimize their costs uh sometimes they are able to see their
exposures uh they're able to figure out they have a lot of resources that probably they needed to optimize anyway
so this exercise done in a with the assistance of a tool in a in a in a
robust manner can actually throw up a lot of positives but having an
understanding of the runtime cloud of the source cloud is very essential so that you do not have problems and you do
not have to iterate back and forth to make sure your target cloud is very
closed if not exactly similar to the source cloud uh the other thing is as I
said earlier is the migration of your cloud security posture your governance
uh compliance security policies you know having a rules engine that allows you to
apply uh these right when you're in the midst of the migration on the target
cloud and having it replicate what you have in the source cloud is extremely important uh otherwise you're going to
spend a significant chunk of time recreating potentially all of that and
maybe missing that in the process uh uh if you're trying to do that manually as well so that's another area we have
found is important to focus and make sure that you're able to migrate uh through an automated manner now one
thing uh I will say a big part of the migration is the data migration which is something uh I'm sure we'll all deal

just even moving the application architecture uh and infrastructure um
from one cloud to the other cloud can be done you know in days you don't have to
take these days months we have had clients we hey we we are engaged with where uh they have had experiences uh in
the past it took them 9 to 10 months to move a few application workloads uh and
in the manual process they went through a lot of pain uh trying to migrate from one cloud to the other cloud and the

righty so you know I I think if we distill down everything that Archer just
covered right um migrating to a new cloud typically ranges from a tedious
experience to quite often a miserable experience all right and uh what I'm going to do is I'm going to go over just
two of of of what I think are are some of the most miserable parts if if done
wrong okay so the first uh I want to cover is unnecessary lift and shift
right so we're all familiar with lift and shift as a strategy right it's uh you know whatever uh application
architecture that we are running from our source cloud let's just move it over exactly the way it is and just use
whatever onetoone uh you know cloud service equivalents exist uh in our
destination right um this is great because it you know theoretically
requires no to minimal refactoring and it usually happens Especially when we
have timeline pressure right we need to migrate to you know XYZ cloud and we
have to get it the whole thing done within within 12 months right a lot of lift and shift starts happening around
month 9 and 10 right so lifting and shifting is is a you know often it's a
go-to strategy but if done wrong it can really defeat the entire purpose of migrating right uh sometimes like cloud
migrations they're done for data sovereignty reasons and and and you know security when it comes to like
regionalization but a lot of times cloud migrations are done just for cost control right something is cheaper to
run in in a in a different cloud let's let's move everything over um a bad lift and shift can really unoptimize the cost
of running our workloads to the point where after a few years we realize cloud migration the migration wasn't even
really that worth it okay um the situations where it is good is it's
great for cloud agnostic platforms right so uh so for example Kubernetes running
uh open-source uh databases or caches you know like Reddus for example um and uh
you know those kind of platforms will be relatively easy to migrate um but it's
not really so great in other scenarios right like when we get out of the realm of like object storage and like
relational DB um uh and like K8 or even VMs like that's when things get tricky
okay so what I'm going to get into is a few scenarios on how we do lift and
shift all right so here what we're looking at is an application architecture where we have a Kubernetes
cluster running on EKS within this cluster we're running backstage few other applications you know just that
part doesn't matter and uh within within this cluster right we are loading in
secrets from AWS secrets manager right we are pulling in container images from
ECR umerts are getting handled uh at the load balancer level uh and we have uh
Amazon route 53 pass setting up our our our DNS and routing tables for us okay
the cluster itself is only really dependent on a external DB service
that's running on Amazon RDS where we have post P post P post P post P post P post P post P post P post P post P postgress SQL okay um if we have to look
at this application and and decide whether a lift and shift is good right
um what we can do is we can go through and look at each of these pieces and figure out okay which of these pieces have a 1:1 uh equivalent and is there
any issue moving it into an equivalent without refactoring right so right off the bat if we start out with uh the you

and then Amazon uh ECR the the services these services themselves are not doing
anything special uh when when you look at different cloud providers to add value right the the real value is what

same with the searchs right um these are very easy to port over into into new

uh and and really you're just migrating all your data into these okay um after
that if we look inside the cluster itself typically when we're going from uh EKS into something like GKE um that
migration is very often like one of the most easiest parts to migrate um going
from EKS to GKE is a little bit easier uh in my opinion because GKE is a more
opinionated managed Kubernetes platform so it's easy to go from a less opinionated one like EKS into GKE where
it'll start setting up automatically for you all the logging the monitoring you actually have to you know you don't have
to do too much the things just kind of automatically get set up for you okay
and uh and then uh Amazon RDS uh if it's if it's running uh Postgress this is um
this is like a a very easy lift and shift target right like going from going
from RDS to something like uh Google's cloud SQL in most cases is like a very
nice and easy transition right like we can set up a equivalent Postgress DB
engine and cloud SQL um set it up with ongoing replication from this you know
uh source RDS instance and uh once that DB synchronized and then we have that continuous uh synchronization going at

Google's Cloud SQL and then we we'll we'll we'll basically be good right maybe there a few staple apps exist

databases right and uh if if we're now looking to port over you know everything

or growth metrics uh quickly extracted right those those uh I guess
transactions are going to take way longer than they would um within Athena
plus Dynamob right DynamoB is optimized for like millisecond response times uh

fire when we're hooking up BigQuery to like any equivalent uh DB system inside
inside GCP okay so you know some other issues are when we look at the when we
look at the GCP setup right there's no built-in data source connector right
here we got very lucky because Amazon has a nice lambda connector interface
that hooks up Athena to Dynamob if we're trying to set up uh if we're trying to
set up like you know like fire store big table as as like the NoSQL uh database

frankly the best solution here is don't migrate all right and and this this is an option that I think a lot of times

um now let's get into the second source uh of misery right and and at a high
level I I couldn't think of a more eloquent way to say this but it's just temporary designs that end up becoming
permanent okay and uh I think a a lot of you folks who are who've joined in if
you guys have done a cloud migration you you've you've probably seen this right so some examples of temporary designs
are you know we're we're migrating clouds and we're going to just overprovision the clusters and the and
whatever compute resources we have right because migrating already is going to take a long time we don't want to deal with performance issues right we're
going to give overly permissive IM roles or or or or principal roles right uh
because we aren't familiar with this new destination cloud and we just don't want
to be troubleshooting IM we'd rather just get the application working right um giving dev teams access to the cloud
console right this you you often have to do this just because dev teams don't
really know what's going on right and and if you if we dig into the underlying issues behind these temporary designs
right the you know devs are not going to want to deal with performance issues when they're when they're going through
a migration devs are want going to want to move fast right and and moving fast
is the opposite of troubleshooting IM roles and and permissions issues right
um and devs need a UI to understand this new cloud system that they're setting up
and having to migrate into right and they need this UI from the console frankly because devs don't know or just
don't really care to know something like Terraform right which which uh is is a
way that you can help uh define it uh through code okay and uh if you if
you're seeing a common theme to the underlying issues behind these temporary designs becoming permanent it's not devs
it's dev experience okay so it's it's this is not the the developer's fault
right this is a developer experience problem and bad developer experience breeds bad behavior all right if we look
at why devs ask for cloud console access right this this is something that always happens right and it's always given just
because it's going to make life easier for the devs right all of a sudden they have access to a wizard-driven setup
guey for setting up whatever resources they need it makes things a little bit easier to understand it's still
difficult to visualize all the resources once they have them set up right you know if I have a DB connected to a
cluster connected to a cache connected to some sort of you know object storage bucket right we still won't be able to
see that whole interconnection but it's going to be easier for us to set it up and know what's out there right and this
access uh this console access right once you give this out it becomes extremely
difficult to take this privilege back away from the devs all right and and
this is how a lot of times we end up with organizations where you know we had to do a cloud migration maybe in the in
the uh or original cloud devs were not really doing too much uh on the cloud
console and you know things were being done through IA terraform or anible configurations you know what have you we
moved to a target cloud and then and then all hell breaks loose we have to we have to basically give devs access
because no one really knows this new system right and and the issues that come out of this are we start getting
unapproved changes right uh folks are doing cowboy deployments uh through the
console itself we have no audit trail when things do change there's no drip detection so we don't even know what
changed right and then you know these three uh just are you know go handinhand
with security breaches okay so the solution to this
is defining IA and ideally also baking and self-service before the migration
even happens itself okay so this this does two things right the first is it's
going to preemptively solve for bad design when we're clicking through and setting up new cloud resources or or or
networking or or a new cloud anything right the clickth through option the click-through path right when we're
doing it through the wizard in the console very often we're just trying to and I'm guilty of this myself right
we're just trying to get the resource stood up right it starts asking for security groups and what I am able to
assume and it's like h okay let me just pick this one I think the other guys are using this too and let's just I just
want my I just want my resource I want my resource and I want it now right like that becomes the that becomes a driving
factor for like for how we do things through the console and this just
inevitably leads to bad design it could be unsecured this could be you know what I thought was a temporary testing
Kubernetes sandbox that ended up getting turned into our QA environment right it could become it could just uh evolve and
grow into a lot of things without uh actually getting fixed right so setting
up IA though the process of that kind of preemptively solves for this bad design right when we set up IA we're going to
be a little bit more careful about what configurations it actually gets loads with right it's very uh difficult to be
sloppy when setting up IA without realizing that you're being sloppy with it okay so setting up these IA templates
for the new cloud infra before beginning the migration is is one of the key ways to kind of just per like have some sort
of control over what's going out there and once it does go out there because everything is versioned and because you
can see the exact configurations right it's easy to then go back and update or upgrade them when you see holes that
need to be patched right nothing's going to be perfect uh uh right out of the gates okay um on top of this right we're
also going to need a way to enforce some guard rails that can make sure that whatever our security posture is is
going to be met in this new cloud right like very often and say we're starting AWS right we know our AWS workloads are
compliant with SOCK 2 PCI uh and whatever else uh you know security
policies we have all of a sudden we move to GCP and then it becomes a wild west right and then security team spends a
year and a half just trying to wrangle everything back under under control right if we set up these proper guards preemptively before anything even shows
up right this is going to save a lot of hassle and even just potential security breaches um when we actually uh are
starting to go live in the new cloud okay um and then the you know the second
the second thing which is simplifying the developer experience this is more to solve that day two problem of once we're
actually using the cloud right if we have dev teams that started with console access they're going to stay on console
access right um and and really the only way that we can get them off of it is to
give them a better alternative uh when it comes to their experience of setting things up okay typically this is going
to look like a self-service infrastructure management uh
slashprovisioning platform okay if devs need infra give them a way to maybe even
like referencing those IEC templates that were you know created in this in this previous thing I just talked about give them the way to just oneclick spin
that up if they need to okay give them access to these kind of templates if they just need to get up and going
quickly but also allow them the flexibility for setting up customized
